comments.content: Don't know this one but I like [Trilby](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/trilby) as substitute.

This looks like an embroidery font that does not seem to match any retail font.  
It seems to have been based on 19th century fonts styles ranging from "Antique" [Egyptian] to Clarendon.  
The serif treatment on \_S\_ seems to be the key to the source fonts.  
Perhaps the closest source might be Kinghorn 205 Med

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Kinghorn205MedAsHMNZS_4685.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/talbot/kinghorn-205/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/talbot/kinghorn-205/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/talbot/kinghorn-205/") which has strokes and serifs all of a roughly equal weight similar to the lettering in the Cap Tallie. There is also a condensed version.  
The reverse contrast -- top and bottom thicker than sides -- shown in the top of \_S\_ in the Cap Tallie might be a quirk of that the digital instructions for that letter.  
Also consider Antique Central Heavy 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/AntiqueCentralHeavyAsHMNZS_5180.gif)
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/aboutype/antique-central/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/aboutype/antique-central/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/aboutype/antique-central/")  
if you want reverse contrast you could consider 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/PTBarnumAsHMNZS_5815.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/p-t-barnum/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/p-t-barnum/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/p-t-barnum/") which suggests the \_S\_ but the vertical strokes are too thin.  
Don

EDITED:  
Larger scale image of HMNNZS PHILOMEL Navy Cap Tally.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HMNNZSPHILOMEL_CapTally_5958.jpg)
  
Larger scale image of another HMNNZS Navy Cap Tally.  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HMNNZSCANTURBURY_CapTally_3923.jpg)
  
Another Navy Cap Tally. 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/cap_tally_hms_neptune_6235.JPG)
  
With the better scale the Clarendon roots are obvious  
Don

EDITED:  
More with a pattern, or patterns, closer to your HMNNZS Navy Cap Tally

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/royal-navy-cap-tallies_5166.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/royal-navy-cap-tallies2_4590.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/hms_hermes_cap_tally_5969.JPG)
  
Some are vintage from before WW II.  
Don

The best match would be a Clarendon with strokes and serifs all of a roughly equal weight, which would differ from an Antique or Egyptian in that some of the terminals, such as those in \_E\_ and \_L\_, are tapered.  
Part way there is Patrick Griffins Clarendon Text Bold

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ClarendonTextBoldAsHMNZS_4966.gif)
  [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/clarendon-text/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/clarendon-text/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/clarendon-text/")  
Don

More letters from the same font or similar fonts

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150201021400im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Assorted_cap_tally_4042.jpg)
  
Don
